14.heading: HBO Films.
14.title: American Splendor [videorecording]
14.author: HBO Films in association with Fine Line Features presents a Good Machine production, a film by Shari Springer Berman & Robert Pulcini ; produced by Ted Hope ; written and directed by Robert Pulcini & Shari Springer Berman.
notes: Originally released as a motion picture in 2003.
Based on the comic book series "American Splendor" by Harvey Pekar and "Our Cancer Year" by Harvey Pekar and Joyce Brabner.

Summary (from OCLC): Pekar is a frustrated file clerk working at the local V.A. Hospital. He is also a comic book fan who befriends the young illustrator Robert Crumb and is soon inspired to create comic books based on his own life. Along his bumpy journey he meets, marries and falls in love with Joyce, an admiring comic book seller.

15.heading: HBO Home Video.

15.author: [No author]
notes: Summary (from OCLC): Animated tale of a man now a "hell-spawn," battling the forces of evil on Earth and in himself. Using his strange powers, he fights to uncover the truth about his identity and fulfill his destiny.
Created by Todd McFarlane ; written by Alan McElroy, Gary Hardwick ; executive producers, Todd McFarlane and Alan McElroy.

46.title: "H.G. Oesterheld, Maestro de los Sueños, 7: De Roland el Corsario a Galac Master"
46.author: Andrés Ferreiro, Fernando García, Hernán Ostuni, Luis Rosales, Rodríguez Van Rousselt
46.appears_in: p. 79-96 in Revista Latinoamericana de Estudios Sobre la Historieta, v. 6, no. 22 (Junio 2006).
notes: "Resumen: la única editorial sobreviviente de la época de oro de la historieta en Argentina, Columba, consigue sumar a su plantel a un HGO que parece producir sus guiones con mayor tranquilidad que in los últimos tiemmpos, y crea nuevamente ricos personajes, como Roland el Corsario, e insufla nueva vida a series creados por otros guionistas."

Abstract: The only surviving publisher of the golden age of comics in Argentina, Columba, was able to add to its contributors an HGO who seems to produce scripts with more tranquility than before, and who again creates rich characters, such as Roland the Corsair, and infuses new life into series created by other scripters.
Abstracts as printed with the article, with some editing of the English.

47.title: "H.G. Oesterheld, Maestro de los Sueños, 8: Un Viaje en el Barco de la Aventura"
47.author: Andrés Ferreiro, Fernando García, Hernán Ostuni, Luis Rosales, Rodríguez Van Rousselt
47.appears_in: p. 155-173 in Revista Latinoamericana de Estudios Sobre la Historieta, v. 6, no. 23 (Sept. 2006).

contents.title: "Como Nace un Personaje de Historieta" (Palabra de Oesterheld) p. 161-163

notes: "Resumen: Es en Editorial Récord donde Oesterheld termina veinticinco años de una profusa producción historietistica que lo convierte, al decir de algunos, en el mayor escritor de aventuras de Argentina en todos los tiempos. Que su elección haya sido la historieta lo aleja del reconocimiento que habría tenido de haber incursionado en la literatura convencional. Que su elección haya sido ser consecuente con sus ideas en la época más turbulente de la vida argentina de los últimos cien años nos priva de conocer todo lo que aún le faltaba contar, en esa que fue su profesión, contador de historias."

Abstract: It is with Editorial Récord that Oesterheld finishes up his prolific twenty-five years of comics production that makes him, it has been said, the most important Argentine adventure writer of all time. The fact that he chose comics denied him the recognition he would have had if he had ventured into conventional literature. The fact that his choice was consistent with his ideas during the most turbulent time in Argentine life for the last hundred years means we will never know all that he had left to tell in what was his profession: storyteller."
Abstracts as printed with the article, with some editing of the English.

164.title: "H2O World!"
164.author: author, Larry Ivie ; illustrators, Al Williamson and Roy Krenkel
164.appears_in: p. 5-10 in Creepy, no. 137 (May 1982) ; reprinted from Creepy, no. 1 (1964).
notes: (The Art of Al Williamson Collector's Edition)
No. 1: "Creepy dons his diving gear for a tale of fear and fantasy."
no. 137: "Why, the divers asked, did such a splendid race of beings hide from the world in a shimmering city under the sea? What did they fear?"
This was the first story Williamson did for Warren, cf no. 137, p. 4.
